{"comments": {"id": 604, "count": 93, "talk_id": 734}, "threadId": 604, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "734", "description": "Traditionally, the Kalandar community of India has survived by capturing sloth bear cubs and training them to \"dance\" through extreme cruelty. Kartick Satyanarayan has been able to put an end to this centuries-old practice, and in so doing discovered a lesson of wider significance: make the practitioners part of the solution.", "event": "TEDIndia 2009", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Kartick Satyanarayan: How we rescued the \"dancing bears\"", "slug": "kartick_satyanarayan_how_we_rescued_the_dancing_bears", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "646", "slug": "kartick_satyanarayan", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Kartick", "lastname": "Satyanarayan", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Wildlife conservationist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/140922_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "Although we are proud of the life we can offer our rescued bears, in the sanctuary, we would prefer that there would not be a need for these sanctuaries and the bears could live unharmed in the wild.", "whotheyare": "Kartick Satyanarayan works tirelessly to save India\u2019s wild animals from illegal captivity and poaching -- most notably rescuing hundreds of \u201cdancing\u201d bears. ", "whylisten": "

Known by many in India as the “Bear Man,” Kartick Satyanaran is the co-founder of Wildlife SOS -- a non-profit wildlife conservation organization famous for its campaign to rescue every “dancing” bear in the country. For many years, “dancing” sloth bears were the only livelihood of the Kalandar community, but the practice involves extreme cruelty by modern standards, endangers the bear population and is illegal today. He began the organization with his aunt and fellow animal rights champion Geeta Seshamani in 1995, and since then they have rescued over 550 bears.

Satyanaran began rescuing animals as a child, with a particular tendency to rescue snakes. Although he majored in business management in college, he returned to his early love of animal as a field assistant tracking tigers for the Wildlife Conservation Society. Now, through Wildlife SOS, he runs rescue and rehabilitation centers for India’s sloth bears, elephants, leopards and more, as well as several conservation and forest watch projects.

would not be a need for these sanctuaries and the bears could live unharmed in the wild.", "whotheyare": "Kartick Satyanarayan works tirelessly to save India\u2019s wild animals from illegal captivity and poaching -- most notably rescuing hundreds of \u201cdancing\u201d bears. ", "whylisten": "

Known by many in India as the “Bear Man,” Kartick Satyanaran is the co-founder of Wildlife SOS -- a non-profit wildlife conservation organization famous for its campaign to rescue every “dancing” bear in the country. For many years, “dancing” sloth bears were the only livelihood of the Kalandar community, but the practice involves extreme cruelty by modern standards, endangers the bear population and is illegal today. He began the organization with his aunt and fellow animal rights champion Geeta Seshamani in 1995, and since then they have rescued over 550 bears.

Satyanaran began rescuing animals as a child, with a particular tendency to rescue snakes. Although he majored in business management in college, he returned to his early love of animal as a field assistant tracking tigers for the Wildlife Conservation Society. Now, through Wildlife SOS, he runs rescue and rehabilitation centers for India’s sloth bears, elephants, leopards and more, as well as several conservation and forest watch projects.

"}], "speaker_name": "Kartick Satyanarayan", "tags": ["activism", "animals", "biodiversity", "environment", "social change", "india"], "title": "How we rescued the \"dancing bears\"", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 432665}]}

title: How we rescued the "dancing bears"

Now, when we started working deeper and digging deeper, we found that it's an illegal act. And even though we're allowed to go to school because they were an extra earning hand at home, so we managed to get education. So we sponsored 600 children education programs. Today we were able to ensure brighter futures for these people. Of course, we had to also get the bears. Then this is what happens to the bears when they come in, and this is what we turn them into. We have ah veterinary facility in our rescue centers. So basically, in 2002 there were 1200 dancing bears and we've rescued over 550 dancing bears. We've been able to ensure a better future for the people and the bears. The big news that I want announced today is that next month we will be bringing in the very last bear off India into our rescue center and India.
